learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate foundational understandings and critical analysis of educational concepts and issues that relate to teaching and learning in a globalised context.
Demonstrate foundational understandings of educational research and underpinning ethical issues.
Demonstrate working knowledge of the academic skills expected in the postgraduate programs in Educational Studies.
Demonstrate collaborative learning skills in cross-cultural contexts.

assessments.task_description:
Between weeks 1-5, students will submit five weekly journal entries via Blackboard (Bb). The weekly journals contain reflections on week 1 to 5 learning.

The purpose of this task is for you to reflect about important aspects of what we are covering/learning in lectures and readings. Each week you may like to spend 10 minutes after lecture to answer the following questions:

  • What was the most important thing/concept/idea you learned during the lecture?
  • What was something you already knew or had learned but it was reinforced?
  • What are your beliefs about teaching and learning in global contexts? Has your belief changed because of the way you have been taught to think critically? Or do you still have the same belief about teaching/learning?
  • What are the implications of learning of this important concept/idea for your future role as educator?

Please summarise your reflection and consider how you may be able to apply what we learn in class to your career and/or to your other subjects in the Master of Educational Studies.

There is no need to write answers to each of the questions. These questions are supposed to serve as a guide for your reflection.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission instructions will be given in class in week 1 and will also be available on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
For this assessment, you will prepare and deliver a 20‑minute oral presentation on one of the assigned topics. Your presentation will be followed by a question‑and‑answer session with your peers and your lecturer/tutor.

As part of your participation, you are required to ask at least one constructive question during a classmate’s presentation. Your engagement as an audience member will also contribute to your mark.

The presentation topics focus on key challenges related to the globalisation of education. They are drawn from the central ideas, debates, and issues explored in course readings, lectures, and learning activities. You will be given a pool of topics, and one will be allocated to you during the workshop.

Your presentation must take a clear position and use a persuasive, argumentative tone. To prepare effectively, ensure your presentation includes:

1. Introduction

  • Introduce the topic and outline the main debates or issues that shape your argument.

2. Persuasive language features

3. Key Concepts and Theories

  • Explain the central concepts and/or theoretical frameworks relevant to your topic.

4. Engagement with Literature

  • Include a minimum of 10 academic references:
  • 6 sources from the course readings, and
  • 4 additional sources from outside the reading list.

5. Main Argument

  • Present a clear, well‑supported argument that responds directly to the topic.

6. Reflection

  • Reflect on your experience preparing the presentation, including any challenges you encountered and the benefits gained.

7. Implications

  • Discuss any theoretical and/or pedagogical implications that arise from your argument.

Each presentation will be 20 minutes long. From this, 5 minutes will be reserved for questions from the audience and/or tutor. Presentations will be delivered live: in class for on-campus students and online for external students. Recorded presentations will not be accepted. You may use PowerPoint slides. Presentations longer than 23 minutes may be penalised.

Presentations will begin in Week 3. All presentations will be recorded for assessment purposes. The topic will be shared with students in Week 1.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students will deliver their presentations in class during the workshop session.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Throughout the semester, you will conduct an interview with one of your classmates about their experiences of teaching and learning (or learning only, if your partner does not have teaching experience). When developing your interview questions, consider how educational experiences are shaped by specific national contexts, as well as the influence of globalised factors on local educational practices. You may also choose to explore your partner’s educational experiences abroad (for example, studying in Australia).

Guidance and practice for conducting interviews will be provided in class.

After completing the interview, you will write a report that includes both a summary of your partner’s responses and an analysis of these responses using concepts and theories covered in the course. In your analysis, you may focus on a single concept/theory or draw on several. For instance, you might examine how globalised educational policies shape individual experiences of teaching and learning.

Your report must also include a reflective section in which you analyse your own educational experiences and contexts, drawing comparisons with your partner’s interview data.

Report structure:

Your report should include the following sections:

1. Introduction

  • State the aims and focus of your project.

2. Methods

  • Describe the interview process, including the techniques/methods used to collect data.
  • You may also include your data analysis approach (optional).

3. Summary of Interview Responses

  • Present a clear and concise overview of your partner’s responses.

4. Analysis

  • Analyse the interview data using relevant concepts and theories from the course.

5. Reflective Section

  • Reflect on your own educational experiences and contexts.
  • Draw comparisons between your experiences and your partner’s interview data.

6. Conclusion

  • Summarise the key insights from your project.

7. Reference List

  • Include all sources cited in your report, using the APA referencing style.

8. Appendices

  • Include your interview questions and transcript.
  • A transcript may be omitted if you provide a working link to the interview recording.
  • You may also include any other relevant materials used in the project.

Further guidance on report writing will be provided in class.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.
